newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Jakarta shares close up on bargain-hunting.
newsitem.headline: Jakarta shares close up on bargain-hunting.

text.p: Jakarta share prices closed higher on Wednesday on the back of bargain-hunting in selected big-capitalised stocks and secondliners, brokers said.
The Jakarta composite index rose 2.60 points, or 0.48 percent, to 542.20 points. Gainers led losers by 45 to 39, with 53 counters unchanged.
Brokers said overall trading was moderate with more bargain hunters came in to floor, bought selected big-capitalised stocks which had discounted since Jakarta riot on July.
"Some stocks were already too cheap, so I think its only a technical and temporary rebound," said Heriadi, broker of Mashill Jaya Securities.
"But overall market sentiment remains volatile on political news coupled with inconsistencies in macroeconomy policy," he added.

Property firm Duta Anggada topped the active list with 15.6 million shares traded, rising 50 rupiah to 2,375 following continued market talk that the company had finalised a joint venture agreement with Singapore-based property firm.
Another secondliner stock Bank Duta rose sharply in late afternoon trading on market talk of a possible management restructure and new syndicated loans.
Bank Duta rose 24.56 percent, or 350 rupiah, to 1,775 rupiah on a volume of 2.2 million shares.
Brokers said blue chip telecommunication firm PT Indosat and cement producer PT Indocement were the target of bargain-hunters.
